description: One of my go to spots when I'm in sf. Located in the japantown plaza, it's in the center. I recommend everything they have! My favorites include their eclairs, and their soup with sandwich combo. The chicken salad is amazing!
author: Shaeli Z.

description:
For a Friday treat, one of our talent brought us some baked goods. She dropped them off on Friday, September 14th around 11:45am.

Last time she brought me something from Andersen Bakery, I told her I loved the morning bun with berries. It had a nice bruleed top which made it sticky and crunchy. Very indulgent! She remembered that, so got a few similar sticky buns. Unfortunately it was salted caramel (I don't like sweet and savory together), so I didn't care for this. But it did have the same texture which I liked. My coworker who doesn't ever finish anything liked it so much, she ate the whole thing. We also got a few assorted muffins: blueberry, mango, raspberry which were standard.

Too bad the sticky bun this time wasn't really my flavor. I still have fond memories of the berry morning bun from last time. Hopefully, I'll get to sample it again.
author: Elena N.

description:
Honestly, this Andersen location dropped the ball. If I could describe my visit here in two words, it'd be BAD SERVICE. 

I was in the area on a Saturday afternoon and decided to stop by Andersen for a quick afternoon snack. I was looking at the pastries deciding which one to order when an older lady working there interrupted me, yelled at me to hurry up and choose one since there was a "line" behind me. I looked behind and there was only one other customer. First of all, the customer behind me seemed like she wasn't ready to order and wasn't in a rush. Secondly, I HATE feeling rushed to order. I was confused when the worker glared at me and gave me a dirty look after she claimed that I was taking too long. I mean, I only stood there for less than a minute. This hasn't happened to me before in the past at other establishments and I found her attitude to be very rude.
  
Even after experiencing the bad service, I ended up ordering an almond croissant, which was wayyy too sweet for my liking. I have a sweet tooth and it was surprisingly too sweet for me. The almond filling inside the croissant was the sweetest part so I had to scrape some of it off. Not only was I was upset with the service, but I was also disappointed in the croissant.  
Another concern arose when I spotted a few flies flying around the pastries in the open display case. Ew, I don't want any flies or their dirty legs touching my food because that's just gross. If this establishment had their pastries in a display case, it'd be more sanitary since flies wouldn't be able to touch the food.

I've been to other Andersen locations in the past and was never as disappointed as I am now. This Andersen establishment needs to step up their game and retrain their employees to mitigate the bad service. I know I won't be visiting Andersens again in the future.
author: Michelle F.

description: Stopped her for a quick afternoon fix. Lots of pastries in the case with fresh brewed coffee. This place is tiny not incredibly clean but it did the job if you're on the move. Their stuff always tastes good.
author: Sanaa H.

description: We had their coffee - medium roast and their Japanese souffle cheesecake. I thought it was the jiggly stuffs but they weren't. So disappointed. It was quite tough and dense. Also, their coffee was really bitter like it'd been roasted for too long. Overall, I can't believe I stopped at this place.
author: Rose F.

description:
Andersen Bakery was a welcome surprise while walking around Kintetsu Mall in Japantown. It was mid-morning and we were starting to get hungry. The bread and pastry display they had looked great.

All I saw and read on their sign was kouign amann and I was sold. We ordered a blueberry kouign amann and a cream cheese french bread to hold us over until lunch. Andersen is also nice because they have a few tables inside their little sectioned off area by the cash register shielded from the passersby.  That's a plus.

The kouign amann was tasty. I really liked it. The addition of blueberry was a nice change in flavors from the buttery, sugar goodness the pastry held. I enjoyed that. The french bread with cream cheese in the middle was well liked also. They came in these little french baguettes. 

Service was fine. Price was inexpensive. Good snack stop while cruising Japantown.
author: Chuck D.

description: I went here an early morning for breakfast. I walked right up and was helped right away! I got a mango tart parfait and an almond croissant from them and they were delicious!! I couldn't stop eating the Mango Tart Parfait! It's rich and full of fresh fruit! The almond croissant was flakey, buttery, and covered in powdered sugar! Really great food, relatively cheap, relaxing environment
author: Libby M.

description:
Andersen Bakery is amazing! They have a wide variety of breads, pastries, cakes and sandwiches available; my friend and I were very impressed by the selection.

Prices were reasonable, and the food was great. We ultimately decided on the cream cheese walnut pastry (boat*), and it was wonderful.

We were stupidly full from Good Belly Crepes, otherwise we would have definitely gotten more. I'll be back!
author: Nic Z.

description:
It's a bakery with a small seating area so it's always crowded. Good coffee, though. Danish is decent-- nothing exceptional. 

What I love are the pork sausage rolls. Remind me of the cheese pretzels I used to get in Germany. It's a pretzel type dough with a sausage baked on top and covered in grated cheese. What's not to love?
author: Tim P.

description:
I had been to the other Anderson Bakery before. Nice to meet it in Japantowm!

I really like the cream cheese walnut! Everything is just right! 

And I had the strawberry cake and a coffee there. 
Good also!
author: Yantong Z.

description: I personally love eating at Anderson's bakery. This place has an amazing abundance of bakery goods for a smaller version of Anderson's. I ordered the jalapeño cheese bread with the one of the young employees. Usually they ask you if you want the bread to be sliced or toasted. I understand that if it was busy that she didn't have time to ask, but it was just me and this other lady ordering. Which the other lady had the other employee helping her. So I paid for the bread and asked her to toast it and slice it. She looked at me for a while like o had some stain on my face and seemed quite annoyed but I didn't care lol the food needs to taste fresh at least ‍ so she finally processed my order and slammed my change and receipt on the counter. So now I have to grab all my coins one by one ‍ and she's like you can go over there and I'll call you when it's ready. Either she didn't heat up my bread or the toaster is broken because uh... it tasted cold and dry LOL the cheese melted a little bit, but yeah... two stars for the melted cheese.
author: Susan K.

description:
This bakery opens earlier than today's Yelp posting of 9 AM time.Yay!!! Lucky for us we came early. I ordered my NF chai tea latte and stayed with hubby's selection of a half loaf of cranberry & walnut wheat bread which they slice right there for you. It was quite healthy!  

By the way if you need napkins ask for it. They keep them behind the counter at the cash register. I believe they hide them back there so it doesn't get messy or for unnecessary clutteredness.

Several ladies were there to assist us too which helped to make the line of customers go faster. Little table seating inside yet cramped. Best to sit out in the mall area even though there are no backs for you. Hubby's back was hurting so we stayed inside the tight squeezed bakery.

The lady in front of me rattled off a long complicated order. I commend the young gals serving her with much patience & kindness despite the rough exterior.

I noticed they sell the Kouign Amann, bacon/sausage pastries, croissants and scones. Plus they have a separate dessert case with more tempting individual sized dessert items like fruit tarts, creme brûlée & more! Check it out for yourself! 

It always packed here bc they happen to be across from Chocolate Chair who are known for their novelty nitro dessert. Because of their convenience right in Japantown West Mall (formerly Kintetsu Mall) hubby loves to get his coffee on & bakery item. 

I'm sure we will be back.
author: Karen K.

description: Jalapenos cheeseb bread! ..try it if you love spicy. Recommended from my wife. And Im now recommended to you all!
author: Hiro L.

description: Waste of money. We ordered the Japanese souffle cheesecake. It tasted frozen, dry and far off from a souffle texture. We had a creme brulee that tasted like a flan. We got a coffee and after giving us our cup the man disappeared so we didn't get enough cream for our coffee. Poor service, horrible baked goods.
author: Karen T.

description: Super dry cheese danish, not crispy at all. Creamy French is very sweet, you can not feel the milky of the custard. Bad experience.
author: Mengrou L.

description: This place is the bomb!  Go and get some bread -- preferably a sandwich made in the deli. Very fresh! The loaves I bought were delicious-- I did not want to share the "pull-apart" at all.  Most people will only want a half sandwich.
author: B T.

description:
Words that come to mind? Shit show. Mind numbing. Dumbfounding. All this while just waiting for a damn cheese bread.

You walk up and order so fast. Then it all goes to hell. The young girl asked me if I wanted it "warmed"

I said--sure. OK. 
Then I stood. And stood. And stood. Twenty minutes went by. The various employees took turns helping other customers. They had tons of bread lined up waiting to go into a two inch wide toaster oven suitable for the Two Dwarves--because the other Five couldn't fit their piece of breadcrumb into the damn thing. 

It was unbearable. Just watching these girls fumble between helping customers and try to warm bread while giggling.

The bread? It was OK. Not worth the ordeal. I won't be back. All that AND you look at the receipt and you just paid an extra 4% for the San Francisco Commie Tax--yeah--I need to help pay for health care. Because that's CA of today. In 10 years look at your receipt and notice the 65% tax for various reasons. You'll complain and then realize you voted for it.
author: Black X.

description: I used to only go to Andersen's for their Creamy French. Today, we randomly decided to get a cake and chose the Cappuccino one. Service seems mediocre here, but pretty friendly. The 6" is a perfect size and it was actually pretty good. The total was $21~.
author: Maggie W.

description:
#87/2016

Sushi and ramen restaurants and a ...bakery? 

On the west wing of the Japantown Center just past the cluster of restaurants that includes  Benihana, you'll find a food court of sorts where Andersen Bakery's located.

I didn't see any exotic French pastries and some of the items looked over-priced and not super fresh. 

I think the majority of the baked goods being in open air on a large countertop and not in vitrines contributed to their looking dry.

They quickly answered "they were made today" but then admitted they weren't made there but off-site. 

I asked the young girl what some of the pastries were and she didn't seem to have a clue. She looked over at a colleague for answers and spoke to me with mixture of annoyance and helplessness. 

Oddly, she queried whether I wanted half or the whole pastry (it was just slightly bigger than average). 

(They sell half pastries? Odd.)

The service was far from welcoming and if I weren't committed to buying something with my little boy's eyes wide with a sugar promise, I would've walked.
author: Jennifer O.

description: A little pricey but what can you really expect to pay in San Francisco? They are known for their Creamy French so we got one of those, a Jalapeno pesto international cheese bread (since we overheard a girl gushing about them), and a sourdough boule. I can't decide if I liked the Creamy french or Jalapeno pesto more. The CF was soft, chewy, sweet and salty all at once. The JC was more hearty savory, and had a good spicy kick! I wish I had time to try more as all their items looked so delicious.
author: Priscilla Y.

description:
Let them eat cake!!!! Good cakes and fast service. 

1. Cakes
You can get good quality, similar to authentic Asian cakes here. As you know they're very different from sugar infused nightmare you find in every grocery store. Not all items are good here, but definitely better than most cakes.

2. Service 
It's fast and on point. Not necessarily the nicest but not rude at all. 

3. Seating 
This place is usually always packed, and they have only 3 tables inside, so it's hard to find any seat. They provide free cup of water, but make sure you check the glasses before drinking. One time it wasn't clean. 

All in all, pretty good cakes sold here compared to most places.
author: Bella J.

description:
If you like RICH and sweet food, definitely your spot. 

I had to try the creme brulee. The sugar on top was super thick and the creme was very sweet and rich. Still good but I think too much unless you have a major sweet tooth 

Got the blueberry pastry and it was not bad! The croissant sides were perfect. I'm not sure if it was preserved blueberries because it kind of had the consistency.... but still good!
author: Jacqui L.

description:
I just had a cup of coffee at Andersen's after walking from the Financial District to Japantown.   A bit of a walk, but manageable. In my 30 minutes at Andersen, I occupied one of the five indoor seating (they have 2-3 outdoor seating). The place is small, but enough to rest up before journeying back to the Financial District (I took the bus).

They are right across from Chocolate Chair (a trendy korean dessert joint selling their famous Dragon's Breathe ----a tasteless gimmick and a waste of your time if you ask me)

Andersen was selling Organic Coffee for $1.95 with a free refill! NOT BAD RIGGGHT?!?

They were selling pastries, baked goods and soups. I don't think they have wifi, but I would still drop by if you want a place to read or chat with a friend.

I don't know the parking situation, but public transportation would be a smarter idea.
author: Thomas K.

description:
If you're in Japantown, a stop by Andersen Bakery is quite essential - especially if you're a fan of bread and pastries. With all the positive reviews I found on Yelp, I knew that I had to give it a try myself. 

Andersen Bakery itself is a small little store inside the West end of Japan Center. There are a few tables and chairs off to one side, but it seems like most people just stop by to pick up some bread before moving on. 

There was a pretty large selection of bread when I came by. All of it was located behind the glass window - and they all looked and smelled heavenly! I'm quite used to the more Asian-styled bakeries where you basically self-serve the bread that you want onto a tray, so I wasn't prepared to tell the worker what I wanted when she saw me hovering over the bread and taking photos. Croissants, Danishes, elephant ears, all sorts of baked breads - I decided to try their popular Creamy French. They're able to help you cut it up into slices, which is nice, and pack it into a waxed bag so the oil doesn't seep out. 

I was tempted to try a slice of cake or a dessert item from their refrigerated section, but opted against it. The Creamy French and its many slices was enough to last me until the next day. The baguette is freshly baked and contains a layer of sweet mayonnaise on the inside. I thought it was tasty, but I wasn't expecting the sweetness of the mayonnaise (or whatever was in the middle). I can definitely see why it's popular - the bread is soft on the inside and crackly on the outside. Imagine that scene from Ratatouille when Colette is describing the fresh bread making that crackly sound to let you know its freshness. Yeah, that's pretty much the bread that they have here. 

Overall, I thought this was a pretty nice bakery to stop by. It's definitely a change from the bakeries I frequent, and I did enjoy the Creamy French, although I probably wouldn't try it again, just because it was a bit too sweet for my liking. When I eat baguettes, I prefer it to be on the savory side.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Date: 11/25/2015  Time: 1:20 PM   55°   Cold and clear

Normally I go to the Andersen at 525 Market Street, SF, for their palmier, almond croissant and the tropical flan before I head back across the bay to get home. However, I was in Japan Town to pick up my favorite cake (coffee crunch) from Yasukochi's for tomorrow's Thanksgiving dessert and my birthday.

As a favor to my oldest sister, I stopped in at this Andersen to get her a palmier. Unfortunately, they were out of almond croissant. Those are the two items that she likes, so I opted instead for an apple cinnamon muffin.

It really does not matter which Andersen Bakery I go to, as the employees are courteous and helpful. The baked goods that I have tried are fresh and delicious. I can never leave without getting a tropical flan.

This Andersen Bakery is smaller than the one on Market Street. It's more like an order to go (on the run) with just a few benches nearby. It is also hidden away in a building housed with several storefronts and kiosks. Get in line, order the baked goodies and/or cakes, pastries, etc., pay the cashier and you're on your merry way.

I will only return to this Andersen when I happen to be in the area of Japan Town. Otherwise, it will be the one near the Powell Street BART Station for my tropical flan.
author: Carol C.

description: The creamy French is my forever favorite. Their chicken sandwich is perfect, especially when paired with the vegetable soup. I love this location - there was a little farmers market right outside when we came in. Dine and shop - perfect day
author: AR K.

description:
I ordered a cake for our holiday lunch over the phone.  I just told them what I wanted, when, how big etc and they took care of the rest.  I came here because it was close to our lunch spot (Benihana) so it was convenient and I didn't have to transport a cake via bus.  Cake was fresh and very yummy.  We got a lot of compliments from our party.

If you are having a party in J-town, definitely order your cake here!  No transportation fuss or muss!
author: Wendy H.

description: The fig and walnut bread was amazing. The mango cream cheese muffin, delicious, and the almond saffron twist might be the best thing I've ever eaten. The customer service was fantastic just as everything else. Been here twice, and will be going back soon.
author: Big B.

description:
Stopped by Japantown today, and got to try Andersen Bakery's delicious treats!
Got myself a slice of the cappuccino  cake while my aunt got a slice of the ganache cake!
All the pastries looked delicious & the service was great c:
author: Gabby O.

description: The workers are often talking in the back and aren't paying attention to non-customers who are buying ice cream from across the store and sitting at Andersen's tables and leaving a mess of cups without throwing them away.  The customer only signs don't work. They need to keep their eyes on the tables and hide less in the back especially the nonasian workers with no common sense.
author: David K.

description:
The pastries here looked beautiful--I wish I had tried more! I went with the kouign amann and was sorely unimpressed. However, the only other one I've had was at B. Patisserie, which is so well known for them that I do not want to unfairly compare. My one recommendation is that if you get one of these, eat it there or quickly turn the box upside down. The crunchy, sticky bottom that is the best part got stuck to the bottom of the box so that when I got home, it separated from the pastry and wasn't as crunchy.

That being said though, I don't want to rate them unfairly. I see that others have tried other things and raved about them. In addition, the staff was SO friendly and nice, I really appreciated that considering most other stores in that mall had staff that didn't even look up or acknowledge us as we walked in. Plus, I only had a credit card on me and they graciously took it without any problem. This surprised me because I typically expect an Asian establishment to have a lot of restrictions around credit card use. Additionally, the atmosphere of the store was clean and there was even some seating.
author: Susan G.

description:
Sure, there are Anderson Bakeries littered all over the Bay Area, but for some reason I always enjoy getting something to go from here. 

The bread is fresh and diverse and they have a lot of options for desserts and food. That's pretty much what you really need when going to a bakery right? 

The service is quick and nice. Not a lot of seating, so you might not have somewhere to eat if you decide that to go is not your flavor of the day. 

Still, I enjoy this place and will continue to buy things from them.
author: Benny H.

description: Great pastries and English bread that they slice for you. Fresh and lasts longer than Trader Joe's bread.
author: Kristan S.

description:
Nice open bakery in the middle of Japantown

This place has been here for as long as I can remember. The open cake counter is always a sight to see, with a large array of colorful cakes and pastries. Passer-bys always seem to stop and stare, which goes to show how visually appealing the food is.

The thing I like about this place is that they use great ingredients (e.g. they serve organic coffee, and put a lot of effort into making the pastries perfect), but they are not in any way hipster or pretentious--they charge very little compared to the quality of food they offer, and you can tell the folks who work there work long hours and have been dedicated to their craft for long time.

Hats off to you, Andersen folks.
author: Henry L.

description: Andersen Bakery is always on our short list anytime we are in the area. There are several locations and have not been dissatisfied once. Our usual stop is the shop located inside Japan Town. Love their fresh breads, cakes and pastries as well as their smiling service. Writing this review makes me feel like driving into the city just to get some more.
author: Bob B.

description: I really like the pastries here. None of them are too sweet or too overwhelming. They're very European/French in style and really light and delicious. I also love this location inside the Japantown, it's always fun walking through Jtown mall and getting a sweet treat from Andersen!
author: Sara S.

description: everything feels so freshly baked and the environment is great. Not the best barkery I have ever been to, but it's high up on the list. Will definitely come back if I come to this neighboor again.
author: Marc S.

description: The loafs and all kinds of pastries are tasty. What I really like is the service. The staffs are very nice and friendly! I always have great experience here.
author: Sabrina Z.

description:
Tried their cheese danish and taste was good, and you can asked them to cut it into slices too.
The place just a small place and you can just sit on the table inside or outside . Price wasn't bad at all
author: Claudy H.

description: Probably one of the best creme brulees I've ever had. I won't lie to you, it's super rich. But let me just tell you, the sugar crust on top is PERFECT and the cream below is delicious. It is very syrupy, but that does not take away from it's delectable quality. Get it, guys.
author: Bushra H.

description: Stopped here recently and had the best almond croissant ever! This little spot was open before a lot of the other shops in the mall, so we grabbed a table and had a snack. A very pleasant place with friendly staff and a beautiful selection of baked goods.
author: Jen W.

description:
I can't leave Japantown without making a stop here for their Anpan (pastry filled with sweetened red beans) to bring home for my mom. 

I don't really care for them but my mom swears that the Anpan that's made here are the best around. For her, it reminds her of the Anpan that she grew up with growing up in post-war Okinawa. Having "sweets," like Anpan was a luxury and so it's a "bittersweet treat" for her. Sure, we have a Japanese bakery in SacTown but, I think it's the "An" (red beans) that definitively stands them apart from the rest. For $1.75 each, it's quite a deal. 

We've been coming here for many years and it's high time I wrote a review.
author: Micki M.

description: I had a matcha cruffin and a strawberry tart. My only critique on the tart would be MORE STRAWBERRIES. The cream was very nice, not too sweet and the sprig of lavender added a little hint of flavor.  The matcha cruffin... it took me longer than I'm proud to admit to realize that a cruffin is a croissant/muffin. Once I got past my blonde moment and dove in for a taste, I was greatly satisfied with my order!! Flaky and delicious. The young lady behind the counter was friendly and courteous! The next time I'm in the city, I will be back.
author: Jessica M.

description: I got the strawberry shortcake and the chocolate cake I can't remember the special name they had for it.  Both were absolutely amazing.  Both were flavored for the japanese palate as the cakes are not overwhelmingly sweet like american bakeries. I wish they had a place closer that made cakes like these in sacramento.
author: Eric K.

description:
Staying at the Hotel Kabuki for the weekend, late Saturday I was planning out what our Sunday breakfast strategy would be. Someplace open early that would have coffee and pastries.  Andersen Bakery fit the bill!

They open at 8 AM Sundays, which is a good thing, because when I rolled into Japantown on a Sunday at 9 AM it was a ghost town - Andersen was one of the very few places open. I ordered a Double Café Mocha, an Almond Croissant and a Raisin Twist pastry. The pastries were fresh and delicious, and my coffee was tasty and perfectly made.

Andersen Bakery is a great option for coffee and pastries for Japantown visitors.
author: David F.

description: I got a anpan from here over the weekend. Filled with red bean paste, it was flavorful. But I found the bread to be a bit stale in taste. Not bad, but for the quality of the anpan in Jtown, it was not what I would have expected.   Maybe the other sweets are better...but that will require another visit.
author: Marck N.

description: I got a few pastry here. The food looks so good and I was excited... then I bit into it and was greatly disappointed. The pastry was not fresh. It was soggy and cold. The Kouign Amann was glazed and baked upside down because the people working there do not know what that is supposed to look like. I threw some of my food out.
author: Clara Y.

description:
Review for what they claim to be,  "Creme Brulee". 

If anyone is going to Japantown in SF today, please do not get their Creme Brulee! JUST got a Creme Brulee from their store and this is how it turned out as. Just check my pic. I was able to pick up the entire glob with my fork and the consistency is super thick and yucky! Condensation happened and caused the Creme Brulee to be super watery. Tossed it away right after.

If you didn't know,  Creme Brulee should be creamy with the right Consistency. The burned caramel on top should crack into the nice creamy custard and not like a net where it eats your spoon and water squirts out.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Andersen Bakery looked small. not sure where the bread/pastry is made. must be baked premade dough. so skipped.

drink: honest tea (1.95 or was it 2.15?)
-price very reasonable.
-"organic" coffee (1.85) also available
didn't see labeling

take outs:
-good location for cheap eats in pricey J-town
-fast, friendly service.
-should be 4 stars for cheapstakes (not me, i'm value oriented).
-table seating available.
author: Victor G.

description: Awesome bakery and good prices.  I had the walnut cream cheese bread and my son had a peanut butter cookie.  Highly recommend both!
author: Michelle W.

description: There is no universe in which the pressed deli meat they served me can be called "chicken breast." This is the most disgusting sandwich I've ever thrown away.
author: Michele H.

description:
Mmm...fresh bread. After having watched the entirety of Yakitate!! Japan recently, I decided that it's important to have fresh bread. The selection here is always great, and the best part is that you can order loaves and get them cut into slices. For those who are interested in portion control, this is an excellent way to do it.

I purchased half a loaf of multigrain English bread, cut thick. I love how they have this option, because it means I don't have to buy the $6 non-fresh-thick-sliced-bread at Nijiya. Half a loaf is $4.50 here and it's just about right for the two-person household I'm in, especially when I'm the only one eating the bread.

Bread, sliced and fresh, tastes amazingly different from the bread that is pre-packaged. I could still taste a bit of the crunch from the crust and the softness of the bread was incredible. I never had this experience with regular wheat bread. Since Japantown is so close to me, there's no reason for me to ever buy non-fresh bread again.
author: Robbin A.

description:
A great spot to go to at Japan town! 

I got the flan ($3.50) and it was good. I wish it was a bit more creamy/smooth, but I was surprised to find cake at the bottom of the flan! If you have a sweet tooth, I would suggest this. 

My friend got the ham and cheese croissants and she said it was delicious. Worker told me their most popular was the cream cheese and almond croissants. 
 
+1 for being a great place to study or catch up with a friend. 

Music is a bit dramatic. Dun dun dunnn..
author: Anna H.

description:
One of the many Andersen Bakeries in the Bay Area, this particular Japantown location offers similar European style pastries and breads with their signature Japanese twist - rational (small) portion size and less sugary recipes. 

I am surprised to find only a limited pasty selection in an early Saturday afternoon. Perhaps they were sold out? I was quite disappointed they did not have any strawberry shortcakes or chocolate cakes. Settled with a slice of their baked cheesecake. It was decent but not very exciting. 

This store is small but there are a handful of tables and chairs around. Doesn't seem to get too busy but do come here early for a better selection of baked goods.
author: Mona W.

description: Haven't even try the bread. I have been in line for 15 minutes just waiting. It is 10 am on a Friday morning. They only have 2 people working.
author: Alice C.

description:
Why haven't I been coming here every single weekend??

I stopped by Andersen on a Thursday after work because I was feeling like indulging in something sweet. I chose the espresso cream layer cake ($3) and raced back home so I could eat it slowly and savor every bite. But.... when I took the first bite it took all my willpower to eat it slowly because it was DELICIOUS! It was even a bit hard to offer my boyfriend some because I wanted to hog the entire thing to myself lol The cream was super light and tasty and the cake layers were moist and perfect. It also really tasted like espresso which was awesome! Sometimes you get a cake or a sweet that is supposed to be one flavor but it doesn't really taste like it.. but Andersen totally hit the nail on the head here, this was the real thing =) 

I'm so coming back here as soon as possible to eat more cake. It's super delicious, affordable, and if you ask for your cake slice to go they will put it in a cute little box. Yay for Andersen Bakery!! =D
author: Sam F.

description: Where are all the kashi pans?? Andersen's was one of my favorite bread stores in Japan. The bakery here in SF= horrible. Where did all of their amazing breads go? They have zero selection. The breads that I did try did not meet my expectations. If you've had Andersen's in Japan don't expect the breads here to taste like that.
author: Sarah G.

description: The cakes and customer service is getting worse.  All the great service workers have left and the replacements do not smile nor say thanks and are robotic in movement lacking common sense as counters are wiped but left quite wet and used wood coffee stirrers are ignored.  Some dumb dumb cut the cakes in tiny slices unlike the ones before, creamy side ends are cut off and discarded on log cakes.  What a waste! Recently, a heavy set European worker was hired and spent most of her time dusting the dust of high shelves onto the pastries.
author: Ken K.

description: The almond croissants were full of air and a thin sliver of almond paste.  The texture was lacking and the best part was the powdered sugar on top.  Other than the appearance, the croissant was a complete disappointment.  My friend complained that his raisin bread was too dry.  Not recommended!
author: Lorissa W.

description: Came here and tried their creme brulee. It was alright but I think wholefoods creme brulee tastes a lot better!
author: Sui N.

description: An odd place for a european bakery, in the middle of Japantown, but they have a couple of items I really like, so it works for me.
author: David T.

description:
The croissants weren't particularly unique - they weren't terrible, but they weren't memorable either. In the meantime, according to my friend the anpan was stiff, and the bean paste was too sweet. 
I also purchased the raisin scone which I thought was tasty but, yet again, nothing worth commenting on. 
Thus, unfortunately, Andersen Bakery in Japantown doesn't bear much semblance to the ones in Japan.
author: Angela C.

description:
Below average bakery. I don't understand all the high reviews, have people never been to a good bakery? 

We tried the almond croissant, an pan red bean bun, pesto bread. 
The pesto bread was very good, nice chewy crust and soft scrumptious middle with pesto. 
The almond croissant texture was not the flaky buttery goodness you'd expect, it was like dry stale bread with almond filling. The red bean bun was so sad, an embarrassment for an Asian bakery. Dry with barely had any red bean. Skip this place and go to any of bakeries in Chinatown (Eastern) or on Clement (Red Blossom) for far superior buns.
author: Kevin M.

description: I love getting the cheesy bread from here. Jalapeño is a hit and pesto is a hit. All the cakes are delicious so you can't really go wrong with anything.
author: Dylan L.

description:
I stopped by Andersen after shopping at Nijiya Mart this past Sunday evening on a whim because I have been recovering from a cold and needed some comfort.  This place reminds me of Sunday afternoon strolls with my mom in Okinawa when she used to take me to go window shopping in town.   My mother would occasionally reward me for my patience after a long morning/afternoon spent traipsing from store to store with shu-cream (cream puff).   I am considered an American HAPA and culturally I am extremely Americanized, but I do have a few memories of life as a child teetering between two cultures and this is one of them.   My fondest memories of both my mother and of Okinawa are cream puffs on Sunday afternoons before I had to return to school on Monday.     So, this place puts a huge smile on my face when I'm feeling a little under the weather or a little homesick.  

On a side note, this place has pretty great brewed coffee.  The eclairs are decent.  My favorite slice of cake is the strawberry shortcake.  They also have thick sliced pan (aka bread).

Slices of cake are a bit steep ($7/slice), but great to share with a friend or a date.
author: Hiromi N.

description: The reason I give this place one star is do to them giving me a cold ham and cheese in which I got a coffee that wasn't all that good.
author: Henry S.

description:
Andersen is a branch but my family regularly visits the bakery so we can get a hold of a couple of loaves of their white bread.

This time, I went to the Japantown branch in that main mall. I shared a cream puff and a Cream French.

The cream puff looked cute but pretty weak in my opinion since it was pretty basic. Whipped cream filling not the richer vanilla cream. Cream French is basically a small, skinny loaf (looks like a bread stick) with a cream cheese middle. It's like cheesecake breadstick so it tasted good. I didn't really like the bread part though, I thought it could have been softer or butterier.
author: Sofia R.

description:
First of all they had Palmiers! Flaky, crunchy delicious ones!

Very pleasant staff behind the corner, quick and simple, what more could I ask for?
author: Tones T.

description: We decided to pick up our 2014 holiday cake here. As far as selections goes, we did not have much choices as we arrived a few hours prior to closing. Our fault. By default, I always tend to buy a cake that is neutral to everyone's liking. Unfortunately their strawberry cakes were gone. However, there was one more chocolate ganache cake left so we took the plunge not knowing what to expect. The chocolate ganache tasted great to our surprise. It wasn't overly sweet or bitter. Perfect! It was a hit at our holiday celebration.
author: Gene B.

description: Cream cheese walnut loaf. That's where it's at. Super yummy and very friendly staff one of the few perks of being in JTown for the hubster. Nice and fresh and fast!
author: Janet D.

description: I recently purchased a 6" Strawberry Shortcake for my boyfriend's Birthday from Anderson and it was delicious! It wasn't overly sweet and the softness was just perfect. The strawberries were fresh too! Everyone complimented how good the cake was! I would definitely say the portion is more for six people than for eight people (best for a small group of party) but, other than that it was an amazing cake and I would definitely repurchase it!
author: Helen C.

description:
A rare Japanese small bakery in U.S.
That is not fancy but a standard local bakery in japan, which is very difficult to find anywhere in U.S.

Reasonable pricing impressed me.

Iced coffee is under $2.
16oz and comes with paper cup.
Tastes actually good.

They have good baked goods and breads as well as some  classic simple cakes.
author: Blue G.

description:
Courtesy or manner is a problem.

I order steam milk and get at least 30% up to 40% froth on top.

I order chocolate croissant and get one that tastes not fresh and after half way through, I didn't see chocolate ingredient in there. 

I order a lot of food, they don't do the minimal table service at all. I have to carry all food to the table. 

I cry for the waitress worked there before. 

Don't go there.
author: Ken C.

description: As close as an Asian bakery can get to a European bakery, their items look splendid and are almost as good as French or German cakes and baked goods (I realize this is a matter of preference, Asian items are usually too sweet and fluffy while lacking the substance of European items). That said, the cakes and breads are pretty darn good. Service is efficient if a bit curt, they could use more of the Japanese courtesy.
author: Tom B.

description:
It was fair. Not quite iike the elaborate open setups of the eki-mae Andersen Bakerys in Japan, but the apple and cinnamon pastries were solid. 

So for all those who wonder why it's in J-Town and all, it's because this is a chain in Japan. :) Just nowhere near as good. I want my buns with wieners and corn! :P
author: samuel a.

description: Definitely stop by if you're in SF! Fresh, yummy bread and nice friendly service :) I really enjoyed the jalapeño bread!!!
author: Joy Y.

description: Absolutely no star. Beware this bakery if you order birthday cake. They took my order about week ago. Just called day before event  !!!they cannot make it cake decorating we wanted. So we want to cancel order. She was trying to charge cancellation fee !!!  DO NOT ORDER CAKE HERE!!!
author: Eric E.

description:
I grew up in Northwest Iowa and lived in an area that was significantly represented by ethnic Scandinavians. I know (and hate) Ludefisk and still wonder how those crown of candles are worn on St. Lucy's Day. And when I take a message from someone named Larson, I always ask whether the end is spelled "on" or "en".

So in a bit of cultural Schizophrenia, here sits Andersen Bakery in Japantown. I ordered a "Long John" for Breakfast and it was OK. The overall selection looked tempting, although it seemed limited. Counter service was friendly enough and I look forward to noshing through the menu a little more in the future. And maybe they could manage a Danish Kringle?
author: Eric B.

description: This place has a good cream cheese danish! However, their ham and cheese croissant was lacking in cheese.
author: Jake S.

description: These Swedish Mazarin mini cakes looked really cool and tasted great. It had an almond liqueur moist cake filling. They adorned the top with halloweeny designs!
author: Derek N.

description:
My boyfriend and I love Andersen Bakery. He loves it so much that whenever we pass by one, he HAS to buy something even if we're not hungry.

I like the strawberry pastries here, and the apple raisin bread, and the fruit salads..
author: Esther Y.

description: Glad to find a bakery. Pastries were light, yummy, and reasonably priced. Located on a busy corner, the small tables afforded a great place to people watch.
author: Bobbi D.

description: Bad Management and horrible young male employee (should be fired). I just live across from this bakery so I buy bread and cake twice a week with them. It is so rude that young male worker give me a dirty look and just stand there in front of cashier doing nothing and redirect me to the busiest young girl working on the croissant side with another cashier side. He is just lazy and I asked for the manager in which I was already upset. He got scared and run into the back pretend he is working with the bread machine. I came every time and leave my number to talk to the manager never got a phone call. Ask to see Manager and got an answer that she only came back at 9 pm to pick up the money. It is a big regret that I seek somewhere else to spend my money now.
author: Eugenia L.

description: Sort of ok. Dessert were too sweet but breakfast pastries were pretty good.
author: Anchisa P.

description:
Stopping in for a light dessert after a large lunch at Mifune Don, my friend and I found ourselves too full for anything more than splitting a single slice of cappuccino cake - though I will admit that I was greedily eyeing the flan, strawberry shortcake, strawberry tart, and... well, just about all their baked pastries as well.

Our slice of cake was delicious though, lightly sweetened, as fluffy as one would expect of Asian cakes, and with good coffee flavor. Perhaps a bit on the pricier side at $2.25 for a small slice of cake, but nothing unreasonable (and we were certainly too full for more than that anyway). 

A note to those who want to eat in, seating here is fairly limited, with about three tables inside, another three outside, and many more people than there are chairs  - seeing as how I showed up during the J-Pop Summit Festival though, I can't speak for how crowded it usually is.
author: Johnny W.

description:
please do not sell pastries that are few days old, even if you are giving 50% off, this is illegal.

I bought few pastries , croissant and walnut bread last night and they tasted like ,not a day old but few days old.

this is very shameful
author: Mason C.

description:
I was so glad to find Andersen Bakery while staying at JapanTown! As a matter of fact I returned two more times just to get Creamy French, which were small soft french bread filled with custard. Yum. 

At one point I got 6 Creamy French. SIX! The lady that helped us at the counter had to go to the back to retrieve 3 more for me because there were only 3  left on display up front. I ate the 6 throughout that day and I was so happy. 

My husband tried a couple different croissants and he liked them. I will probably try some of the other pastries next time I visit, but only if I have any room left after a few Creamy French first.
author: Yiching P.

description: Cakes are light, creamy, and delicious. Coffee is just as good.
author: Alexander T.

description: Wen't here for semlor (Swedish pastry), it was good but the place it self was not so clean.
author: Rebecca B.

description: I loved this place. The ladies in the store were so nice and informative. They have a eclectic collection of pastries. I opted for an almond croissant and it was amazing accompanied with a smooth soy latte. The place is rather large so there was plenty of seating. I would definitely go back.
author: Angel L.

description: Got the strawberry tart and a tea. The green tea is really good and the water is nice and hot. The strawberry tart was really good if a bit too tough. It was hard to bite through the crust. I thought it was odd they garnished their tart with rosemary. The staff was a bit slower than desired but they were a tad busy that day. I would choke here again for a nice snack and tea.
author: Deanndra C.

description:
To me, Andersen Bakery always looks a bit oddball next to all the other shops and eateries in J-Town. After all, it's a European-style bakery amid the more familiar manju and mochi sweets. But I have come to realize I am the one who is guilty of prejudice when it comes to what my peeps want to satisfy a sweet tooth. Yes, who am I to judge the taste buds of my samurai brethren?

In a weak moment, I came here on Saturday full of good intention to simply stare at the baked goods on display. When the server in the corporate uniform (it is a retail chain after all) asked me in a most robotic fashion what I wanted, I had to give in to temptation and order the Pan Dolce and a Cheddar Cheese Croissant.

For Chrissakes, I said it was a weak moment. Don't judge me. Both were $2.95. The Pan Dolce was a very dense piece of sweet dough mixed with cream cheese. Honestly, it was more chewy than tasty and not quite the thrill I was expecting. More predictably, the croissant was nice and flaky, but the mix with cheddar cheese - not my favorite kind, more like high-grade Velveeta if you ask me - was not the best thing for my palate much less my stomach. I'm going back to the Benkyodo peanut butter manju next time.

PASTRIES - 3 stars...looks better than it tastes...dammit
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a wee bit of Switzerland in the middle of Tokyo...whatever
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...robotic would be putting it kindly
TOTAL - 3 stars...but have you tried the manju lately?
author: Ed U.

description:
7PM on a Sunday and I am in need of a birthday cake. I was searching on Yelp and stumbled across Andersen Bakery after calling several other bakeries in my neighborhood- everything was closed! Safeway was my very last resort but I really didnt wanna go there. I was so happy when a friendly voice picked up and told me they were still opened for another hour. I asked her to save me the 6" cheesecake and 6" strawberry shortcake- I was there in 5 minutes and picked up both!

Everyone at dinner enjoyed them both. The shortcake was very moist and the cheesecake wasnt heavy. Definitely a nice treat after dinner.

Thank you, Andersen Bakery, for closing at 8PM on a Sunday!
author: M W.

description:
I loved Andersen Bakery in Tokyo. It was exciting to find a store here.

I now have a "cup of coffee + oat nut cookie" morning at Andersen way too often. I find the organic coffee unusually good.
author: Kenneth H.

description: Looking for a quick snack at Japan Town, I decided to stop by Andersen Bakery for a tomato soup. Unfortunately, the soup was a huge let down - it strangely tasted like flour rather than tomato. In addition, the sour dough bread was plain and dry. The only highlight was the great variety of vegetables in the soup. Yelpers, do not get soup at Andersen Bakery.
author: May Y.

description:
Food is good, though not spectacular.  People are usually pretty friendly.  Service is exceptionally fast, and not just by Bay Area standards.  I was told this was a Japanese chain - in which case I'd be inclined to chalk up the fast service to that.

They don't charge sales tax on to-go orders, as well they shouldn't.  Not everyone seems to know to-go food in California isn't taxed, because most restaurants charge it anyway.  I often wonder what these restaurants do with the tax they shouldn't be collecting in the first place...  The cynic in me says they just pocket it themselves as extra profit margin, but I guess that's harder to do on card transactions.  I digress.

I wish they had wifi.
author: C L.

description:
[M]ona: 3 Stars
[W]ayne: 3 Stars
Average: 3 Stars

+ Accepts Credit Cards
+ Not Pricey

- Food looks better than it tastes
 
[W] I normally come here for the sandwiches and salads which are ok. It just feels like I can make these stuff at home especially the creme brulee haha. Anyways, we got the creme brulee, tropical flan and cappicino cake this time.

[M] The Creme Brulee http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/FTir7qcSlmO3il2rSi0urQ?select=O_gn_3aYH2Hgk--oE6IBTA here tastes like the one Wayne makes but it's more on the softer and sweeter side. The brulee part was not hard/crunchy so that's a dumbs down for me. The Tropical Flan http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/FTir7qcSlmO3il2rSi0urQ?select=KI9_D2DY-62Kgn-tDmsgNg was EXTREMELY bland. 

[W] I believe that all Andersens are the same. I haven't found one that excels over the rest. Nothing too much to say about this place. It's a great choice if you want to eat healthy and too lazy to make your own sandwiches
author: Mona C.

description: I bought a chocolate cookie and an eclair for my husband and I, as well as a loaf of bread. The snacks were rather bland, my cookie having no hint of chocolatey flavor. I was hoping to get my garage ticket validated here, but I'd have to spend $30, so that was a no. Still the little shop is cute and the person helping us was nice.
author: Genevie Lei L.

description:
The strawberry shortcake is my favorite thing in the entire world.  And the bread.  I don't even live in Norcal and I was heavily contemplating that I should buy a loaf of bread to take home... but decided against it because:

1. I already bought too much food to bring home

2. The loaf would've disappeared before I even got home.

I love this place.
author: Jenn C.

description: Japanese delicately sweet pastries with good organic coffee. Also bought some anpan to go for the kids ;)
author: Reiko B.

description:
pros...if you are in jtown and are in desperate need of some snacks or some bready things, this is a great place.  open early and closes late, this is a perfect place to have some breakfast or a little light snack after dinner.  

we had went here early on friday, and it was open at 9am, which is early for the japantown center.  the service is awesome, as they will get your stuff and even heat it up to the perfect temp.  we had ordered the cheese danish which is the best danish i have ever had.  and if you know me i love danishes.  this one is made with the same type of dough as a croissant.  so it was light and flaky as well.  the cream cheese was light and not too sweat at all.  and the whole thing when warmed was just perfect.  i also had the sunshine bread, which is bread with a very thin sugar cookie dough baked on top.  so good.  

the coffee here is great, fresh and served with a smile.  and the servers here are very proud of their products and the service they provide.  they are very intent on making things perfectly.  my wife had order her drink and it was the wrong size, and they just didn't add extra to make it the right amount.  they of course threw the old one away and got the correct size cup and then redid the drink again.  the new girl made really good steamed milk.  perfectly light and airy.  

cons...wish we had one here in San Diego.  it's quite a bit aways for us, but when in japantown this is the place to go.
author: Joel G.

description:
Yum baked goods. I've been to this location a few times in Japantown for tasty goodies and bread. This weekend we grabbed some garlic cheese bread and a cheese & bacon bun. The bread was soft and fresh and oh so awesome. 

They don't only sell baked goods and pastries for immediate eating, you can get buns and rolls in a bag to take home. I should make a point of popping up here every few weeks to get fresh bread products.
author: Cassandra J.

description: Best bread around JapanTown area. Coffee is not really great, but this place is just worth by its bread.
author: Edgar S.

description: Croissants weren't buttery enough. Eclair tasted bland. French cream bread was tasty and service was good.
author: Chris B.

description:
I have a soft spot for this place.  For as long as I can remember, my grandmother used to come here and meet up with her friends every Saturday afternoon.  They would sit in the exact same spot, exchange stories, drink coffee, eat some pastries and then continue on their day.  I used to meet my grandmother here often and we used to laugh and talk, before she got really sick.  I miss those days. 

There's an assortment of goodies but I always ordered the fruit tart and coffee.  She would order coffee ice cream and we would share desserts and then sit and people watch; gander at tourists as they excitedly talked about cherry blossoms, or how fascinating Japanese culture was to them.  She grew up during the time when Japanese imperialism reigned over Korea.  Therefore, she had to embrace the Japanese culture by learning the language and by attending a Japanese school.  But, she never saw this experience as negative (as most Koreans would during that time), but alas, as a positive, learning experience.   I marveled her tenacity and strength.  She loved coming to J-town and Anderson's because to her-- it was a second home.  

I passed by Anderson's a couple of weeks ago, while having dinner in that area, and it was bittersweet.  I would do anything to be able to talk to her again.
author: Soo Jin K.

description: Anderson bakery is great place for a snack in the middle of the day. The coffee is good and it's very nice place to hand out for couple of hours. The line is not to bad most of the time. Today is was busy but we had a small event in japan town. So enjoy it
author: Magen B.

description:
A reasonably priced place in Japan Town. Their sandwiches are great for lunch.

All of the sandwiches are priced the same so I went with the one which had the most appealing bread and size which was the chicken and provolone sandwich. It was surprisingly very delicious! I loved the pesto mayo and the bread tasted very moist, soft, and fresh! The clam chowder was delicious as well! Just overall a great place for a quick lunch! 

The pastries and other breads looked very alluring as well, but I was only there looking for lunch, and Andersen Bakery saved the day!
author: Kevin T.

description:
I came in here on a Thursday afternoon for coffee and cake.  The coffee was slightly above average, and fresh. 

I tried a slice of cappuccino cake, which was outstanding.  I'd recommend trying a few of the dessert options here.  

With so many food options in Japantown, it's usually hit or miss.  However, Andersen Bakery is a hit for me.
author: Ravi M.

description: I tried their Kouign-Amann, and it was SOOOO good!  I want to try their everything!  Great job!
author: Yasmin T.

description:
Came here around 10am on a Sunday to grab some iced coffee and some breakfast. 

Unlike its usual bustling atmosphere, Japantown is relatively deserted around that time. It was a pleasantly quiet ambience sitting outside at Andersens though--and by outside I mean in the indoor plaza (too windy in the real outside).

We shared a jalapeno cheese bread and a "sunrise" (a.k.a. melon-pan).

They sliced the jalapeno cheese bread for us--it was yummy! Airy and soft, with just a hint of jalapeno with some creamy sauce on top. 

If you  haven't had melon-pan, it's a Japanese bun that reminds me of Cantonese pineapple buns--baked bun with a cookie-like crumble stuck on top. The one here wasn't too flavorful--A said it didn't quite do "real" melon-pan justice. 

Iced coffee did the job. Not much to say there.

We were going to buy bread, but it was a bit pricey so we passed.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Only like their creamy french breads. Their cakes aren't good and comes in small slices. 

I tried sharing some of the cheesecake with my dog and it was rejected. He loves to eat in general, but didn't eat this after a sniff. Something to think about.
author: Alisa M.

description: A pretty standard bakery. Came here while waiting to do "escape the room"across the street. The apple muffin was the right level of sweet, I think muffins are too often way too sweet. The apple chunks were tasty, and for two bucks I can't complain. The creme brulee was also good, a bit more expensive (3 bucks). The top layer of melted sugar was incredibly sweet, a little too much, but the custard underneath is on point. It balances the sweetness of the top layer, so as you take a bite the flavors change as you chew them. On the whole, both things were good but were nothing spectacular.
author: Amaresh S.

description:
This place is great for picking up some baked goods early in the morning.  I jogged here around 9am when they had just opened and asked for the strawberry tart.  There were none made yet but the lady soon had a fresh batch ready for me.

I also got a half loaf of the cinnamon raisin bread, which was an incredible value for the money I spent on it.  It lasted about 4 meals.  Most amazingly, I left half of it for 10 days when I went on vacation and, upon returning, found that it was as fresh as it was the day I bought it.
author: David H.

description:
A good place for breakfast, snack or dessert.
Blueberry cream cheese pastry bun = yum, very good.
Bacon and cheese pastry bun = serious yum with bits of bacon.
The coffee was mild but tasted good. 
I was kind of sad the next morning when I wasn't eating pastries from Andersen. They must be very good.
author: Evelyn T.

description: I come here for the strawberry shortcake and morning pastries when I miss being in Japan. The cakes here aren't too sweet, maybe not sweet enough by American standards but freshly baked and delicious :)
author: Akiko E.

description: Meh. I was disappointed in the one 'pastry' that I bought. It was some kind of bread with tomato sauce & cheese on it. I asked if she could heat it up for me & it was put in the microwave. I thought it would be toasted atleast. I ate it right away & it was still cold & I swear, it tasted a little moldy. Trust me, I have a pretty good palette, & unfortunately, I know what mold tastes like.
author: Alysha K.

description: Super friendly and efficient staff. Free water as well! Ha!
author: Royal B.

description:
The presumption is that if a bakery is in Japantown, even with a name like "Andersen" - it's going to be good. It does not disappoint.  Croissants are light and flaky, but the ham and cheese croissant was disappointing...they shouldn't roll up all the ham where it's balled up in one spot - it needs to be spread out over the whole croissant. The oat-nut cookie was delicious as was the soft french baguette filled with custard - yummy.

I enjoyed the strawberry cake but was disappointed in the flan - the flan had no taste even if the texture was as flan should be. You bet I'll be back to try the other items - overall, I would expect it to be way above average.
author: Dee Z.

description: We just got walnut chease bread and its awesome and my son told me that is the best bakery in the world
author: Zhaleh B.

description: the service was friendly, the customers were too ^_^ I like that, but the food is... ok. its not horrible, just decent. I must be picky but I wouldn't mind eatin here again if I was in the mood for some coffee or something. I didn't try the "ultra" sweet cakes or pies but it does seem a little pricey for it. the morning bun is alright. but I suppose the  highlight of the place is that it accepts ATM and has nice customer service.
author: Debby D.

description:
Since they are located conveniently inside San Francisco Japan Town I have bought bread from them multiple times.
They are good, but if you have time I recommend you to go and stop by the Daily City location.
There are multiple times I felt their breads were a few days old since they do not bake them here.
You can order the exact same thing and pay the same price and get much better quality at the Daily City location. (except for sandwiches)
Unlike the sandwiches at the Daily City location, the sandwiches are pre-made and smaller.
However at the Daily City location, you have to pay a little more(I thing a dollar or two) the they are made to order and a little bigger in size.
author: R O.

description:
I like Andersen Bakery.  They have yummy breads, pastries, and desserts.  This last visit, we got an almond croissant, chocolate croissant, strawberry pastry, and blueberry pastry.  They were all super good.

I haven't tried any of their desserts yet, but they look really yummy.  

Andersen Bakery is a good place to stop by in Japantown when you want some snackity-snackums, but don't feel like having Japanese food.
author: Kris L.

description: This place is AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS! After doing some shopping during the Cherry Blossom festival, I worked up an appetite for something sweet so I bought a slice of a strawberry shortcake from here. It was like taking a bite of heavenly goodness! It's not overwhelmingly sweet or heavy, like how most places make their cakes. The cake was incredibly light and the strawberries took center stage in the flavor department. It was so good that I ended up buying a whole cake! The only downside is that the baked goods are pricey; however, they are worth every penny! Besides, its good to treat yourself every now and then.
author: Paulamertha A.

description:
After leaving Nippon - Ya, we veered toward Andersen Bakery, because my sister loves their custard bread (small loaf of french bread, sliced in half and filled with custard) and several of their cheese loafs (rounds of bread, baked with pieces of pesto cheese on top).

I'm not much of a pastry or cake indulger.  Only because I'm a little finicky with my sweets (I prefer the heavy use of butter and cream, so more inclined toward French cakes and pastries) Japanese cakes lack the heavy use of dairy and butter, so its a mild sugary sensation.  My sister loves their little tarts topped with fresh berries, as well as their mocha chocolate cakes.  These slices are around $3.00 each.  The custard bread was around $2.00, and apparently, prices had gone up.  

In addition cakes, they also carry pastries ranging from croissants to pinwheels, as well as muffins, danishes, and baked breads.

There is seating on the inside and the sales staff were helpful, all smiles, and quick.  We were out within a span of 10 minutes.
author: Miika M.

description:
While in town a few weeks ago, my sister and I decided to stop by and look at what goodies they had in store after we had lunch. Their Strawberry Shortcake caught our attention, so we ordered a slice to share. Apparently, one slice wasn't enough for the both of us. She ended up buying a whole cake, so we could take it home and indulge on the amazingly delicious, moist, yet light cake. Just thinking about it makes me want another slice!

Customer service was excellent! The man that helped the both of us was genuinely nice and had a smile on his face as he helped my sister and I. I definitely want to make another trip out to San Francisco to order another shortcake, but I would also like to try their Chocolate Ganache  and Dream Cakes. Anything that has chocolate in it, I'm sold!
author: Ardella O.

description: Their bread is really good. No Seriously. Try it. They have the pesto and cheese bread here but not at their  FIDI location. What is up with that? Eclairs were stellar too. I am addicted.
author: Lost B.

description: When I first saw this famous Japanese bakery in Japantown, I was excited, but I soon was disappointed when the product differed greatly from the stores in Hiroshima and Tokyo.  I used to be hooked on Andersen store in Roppongi.  It was in the same building as my office, so I used to go there twice a day, each day trying a new creation.  They had so many choices and each one was out of this world good.  If you have any plans to visit Tokyo, definitely go to Andersen.  I just don't understand why they decided to drop 90% of the creations when they came to the U.S.
author: トモ T.

description: Really delicious, fresh breads and pastries here. My personal favorites are the pizza bread and the jalapeno bread; both are large and have plenty of toppings, but aren't drowned in them and allow you to still enjoy the crisp bread itself. Their sandwiches are also delicious as well and don't skimp on the meat and fillings. They always have samples for you to try many of their various breads and pastries. Everything here is reasonably priced and I feel you get good quality for what you pay. This particular location always has a line, so just be prepared to wait a while.
author: Angela M.

description: A lot of variety of baked goods.  Everything looked great and was very fresh.  We bought some of the cheese breads To Go.  Had a chocolate croissant that was flaky and soft with a good cup of organic coffee.
author: Mary V.

description:
Weak-willed people like me should not be allowed within 1000 feet of this place :(  You'll want to buy everything because it all looks so good.  I've had many items from here before, most notably the bacon and cheese roll, the tropical flan, the strawberry tart, the country sourdough, and the dream cake, and the stuff I get is usually great.  The sweets aren't too sweet - not overly sugared American-style sweets, but more like a subtle, perfect amount of sweetness such as Japanese or European pastries and desserts would taste.  This is a good thing :)  I also love how super friendly and helpful the staff is - always smiling and patient when you're trying to figure out which three of the ten tantalizing things you're considering purchasing you'll actually end up buying.  Not much seating inside, but the stuff is small enough to take with you and eat on the go anyways. 
 
I'd go here every day if I lived nearby :/
author: Irene W.

description: The pastries are decent and decently priced. Not the best I've ever had, but the chocolate croissant was still pretty darn good.
author: Mage L.

description:
Stopped by for a ham and cheese croissant. Looked delicious. The trainee puts it on a plate that has a good size piece of wilted lettuce stick to it. Obviously it's a dirty plate. When I pointed it out to him, he pulled it off with the same tongs he's using to grab the pastries. And then puts my croissant back on the plate!!!!  I have to tell him it's unsanitary and to change out the plate, which he does. The tongs get reused. 


Good food. Questionable sanitary techniques at the front counter.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
3.3/5 i love asian bakeries

it's not necessarily a stand-apart from other asian bakeries, but i love them so. after a nice sushi dinner, it's nice to pick up a pastry on your way out of the mall, or stash a few for later when you get the munchies!
author: Alvin D.

description:
QUINTESSENTIAL JAPANESE BAKERY

In addition to everything American, the Japanese also have a fascination with everything French.  And they bring it into their culture, mix it up with a pair of chopsticks, roll it up in a bamboo mat and deliver it Japanese-style,

This bakery is kinda French, but it has definite Japanese sensibilities. Nonetheless, the goods are delicious! My favs are the plain old white bread...it looks like a loaf of Wonder Bread, but the texture is slightly chewy with a nice yeasty aroma when toasted.  Good french breads -- not your crusty Artisian style like a La Brea, but toothsome and flavorful.

Their pastries are rich yet delicate and not overly sweet.

Eat, eat and be merry.
author: Rita S.

description:
Five stars for the Creme Brulee. It's far more satisfying than most $9 restaurant versions. Everything else is not valuated in this review.

Order the Creme Brulee and that will be all that is needed. 

The fruit cup w/ flan/custard is watery and lacks sweetness, caramel flavor, and flan flavor.
author: Chris L.

description:
I get the jalapeno cheese roll all the time.  It's the best!  Cheesy, crispy and hot.  It's always cooked to perfection.

I've tried the pesto roll and their chicken salad sandwich.  Both are good.  The chicken salad sandwich was a fresh and tasty surprise.  Nothing is as good as the jalapeno roll though.  I could eat them every day.
author: Brian K.

description: Andersen's farmers chicken salad sandwich on PDC bread is really yummy. Love their creamy frebch too.
author: Hazel M.

description: The jalapeno/cheese bread is good and so is the cream filled bread. Sadly, that's the only thing that I like here. The creme brulee I had before was really gross. And I didn't care for the pesto bread either. If I was just judging the jalapeno and cream bread, the re would be more stars for sure.
author: Kay S.

description:
I'm always sad when I'm hungry two hours after I finish my lunch...which is what happened after my lunch at Andersen Bakery.

I ordered the chicken and avocado sandwich - sounded tasty to me!  When I got back to my desk at work, I eagerly unwrapped my sandwich to find a big mound of bread.  I literally had a triple decker...of bread...oh wait, was that a piece of meat in there....oh, and is that a piece of avocado...??  My microscopic portions of sandwich toppings were really disappointing.  I was so puzzled, I showed my sandwich to my co-worker (who ordered the same type of sandwich); he was also puzzled because our sandwiches looked nothing alike.  Needless to say my bread sandwich was very unsatisfying.

Though I didn't get it on this trip, I do love that International Cheese bread.  Delicious...
author: Wendy L.

description: Awesome Japanese pastry with great price.. new product puff pastry is very good...  had cappuccino cake ... and coffee...  all great to my surprise
author: Sam A.

description:
THE place to get yummy, fatty Japanese breads : D

Andersen Bakery is a famous bakery in Tokyo.  I grew up eating breads and cakes from them.  Asian breads tend to be silky and fluffy, and a simple loaf of sandwich bread would contain more milk/butter/flour/yeast=more calories/fat than a typical sandwich bread you might find at a grocery store here in USA.  But how can we say no to that, it's just too good!  My preference for breads have always been in the order of 1) Japanese breads 2) French breads and artisan bakery breads 3) Make my own 4) American generic breads.

I usually get a half or full loaf of white pullman bread, thick sliced, and a loaf of raisin bread, and store them in my freezer.  They make great toasts, sandwiches, french toasts, and "honey toast" (Japanese dessert where you sautee cubes of bread in butter until crispy on all surfaces, then drizzling honey on top).  I also get chocolate croissants for my husband and blueberry pastries for myself.  

I also love that they are a convenient, light snack/brunch dine-in option too.  They serve basic coffee/teas, plus a few bottled drinks, and ready made (but nonetheless quite fresh tasting) sandwiches, cakes, custard flans, eclairs, and recently started offering a couple of kinds of soups too.

My favorite dine-in option is their soup and sandwich combo.   For $6.50, you get a small cup of your choice of soup (I get their clam chowder), and you get to pick a sandwich from their selections (I love their chicken salad sandwich.  You can usually choose from plain white bread and raisin bread. I prefer the raisin bread, as the sweetness of raisins go well with the chicken salad)   I often get this for a light, quick brunch... portion is not as filling as a typical, heavy American breakfast of eggs, sausage & potatoes with bread, but my stomach usually takes a while to "wake up" in the morning so often times this lighter portion suits me better.  It's not going to weigh you down, but it's filling enough to keep you happy for a few hours until lunch or snack time.  

I sometimes get earl grey tea with it too, but because the soup is piping hot, lately I've been just getting self-serve free water that's set up by the sit down area.  

In a city where there's lots of good food but most of them are pretty pricey, their price point and convenience is a great find! And they're yummy too.  Perfect!
author: Sascha O.

description: Their creamy french is the best.  Love it.
author: Emily L.

description: I bought the creme brullee....I've had better, the custard was good but they failed on the sugar coating.  I also bought some walnut bread with cream cheese, those were very good.
author: Josie Y.

description: I've never tried their cakes but from the looks of other people's reviews this place might be better for that. I've come by a few times to get their sweetbread, and the texture was just not what I consider as outstanding. Still not sure which part of their baked goods are considered French, but my blueberry cheese bun was a little heavier on the dough with no filling, and lighter on the spread of cream cheese and blueberry on top.  This was similar to my experience with the an pan which I thought was not mind blowing or enough to cause a riot. Since they each cost about $1.75-ish I thought the price was pretty high. Service was friendly and thoughtful as they microwaved my order so I can taste their best. I'm not sure if they would receive a similar high rating if it's not located in Jtown, and by the end of the day their pastries just didn't look good at all. Three stars for my experience.
author: Daniel L.

description: Yummy pastries and hot delicious soup!  They had a light sandwich and soup special for $6.50 right now.  I got the turkey sandwich and clam chowder which were delicious.  Their desserts isn't overly sweet like many other places, and they are reasonably priced.  The raspberry cream cheese danish was sooo good!  Its texture was just like a croissant, flaky and delicious!  They would have gotten five stars, but there's no refills on drinks and there was also no condiments available.  I like having some mayo in my sandwiches.
author: Julia N.

description: Turkey pepper jack sandwich: good. Interesting: halves were wrapped individually.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I still have wonderful memories of my dad bringing home bread and dream cakes from this particular location.  I think the dream cake is completely divine.  Chocolaty, but not heavy, since it uses whipped cream for the frosting.  It uses cocoa powder in the cake itself, vs. chocolate, so less fat is added in.

I am also a tremendous fan of the Japanese bread here. It makes the best grilled cheese sandwiches on the planet.  It's not cheap, but to be honest, the price of wonderbread keeps rising, so at the end of the day, I'd rather have really good bread for a few cents more a slice than the processed stuff.
author: Erin O.

description:
consistently decent 3.5 stars

i have tried their strawberry shortcake here, its decent, the cake is light and fluffy but their whipped cream sometimes feels like theirs too much. i love their flan with mixed fruits....its not too sweet and its a nice touch with the fruits with it. 

all their cakes look yummy, i want to go back and try more
author: Stella J.

description:
Mmmmmmm.

The price is right for a snack, and everything I had was fabulous.  We went there twice in two days for mid-shopping snacks and got the "International roll" (a basic roll with cheese melted on, and pesto I think) some basic rolls, and creme brulee along with coffee.

The creme brulee was surprisingly yummy, very decadent, and around $3 if I remember correctly.  The coffee was also surprisingly good, as bakeries frequently overlook that.  

Service was also prompt and friendly.  When they ran out of coffee, the girl at the counter replaced it immediately!  

I really wish there was one of these where I live!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Oh my, creamy French baguette.

Being an Andersen virgin, I decided to throw it all out the door this morning when my hunger and lack of breakfast items in my cupboard took over and drove itself to Andersen

Three words:  creamy French baguette.  It's a fresh loaf of French baguette filled with a very light, mild vanilla custard.  At first I didn't know that there was custard in the baguette (I just figured that 'creamy' referred to the texture of the bread being very soft) and it took me by surprise at first.  After eating the whole loaf, I decided that it's on my list of favorite things to consume.

I also scarfed down a chocolate European cupcake, which is pretty much like a very almond-y cupcake sans frosting, but with chocolate chips on top.  Light, moist, super delicious as well.

I'm in the process of finishing up my chocolate croissant and raspberry cream cheese strudel, but I can tell you that the 5-star rating still stands.

This is my new favorite place to go for some guilty breakfast pleasures.  Ooh, I'm cheating on my diet..
author: Tori S.

description:
It's not a cheap loaf of bread (the half loaf of white pullman bread goes for $3.50), but it definitely is delicious!  I sometimes make a run over to Jtown specifically to pick up a half loaf.  I'm a crust girl, and so I just love how the crust on this bread is thick but not crunchy-- just the right amount of chewiness and carby goodness.  And the white insides of the bread?  SUPER soft, a little savory, and just perfect for making a great sandwich (or, if you're like me, for chomping on when you have a hankering for filling 200% of your carb quotient of the day :D  I can't help myself-- I love myself some carbs-- esp bread!).  Honestly, a couple slices of avocado and some soy sauce or salt spread generously over a browned slice of this bread?  Good lord, I am salivating now thinking about it . . .  :D

I haven't ordered their other breads and buns specifically, but I've tried the samples, and they're all pretty good, standard Japanese breads (or, at least, the Japanese take on European-style pastries).  Tasty, and worth it if you want a good snack.
author: Jeanne Y.

description: Their pastries are pretty good, but seems a bit too thin! Not that pricey, and feels good to treat myself here when I'm in Japantown.
author: Soo Jung R.

description: Awesome quiet little bakery that also made a bomb chai latte. Perfect for waking up in Morro Bay
author: Kevin B.

description: Good bread!  i usually get the ham and cheese croissant, anpan and the iced tea.  bf and i like it here a lot.
author: R F.

description:
A great bakery that really takes me back to Japan :)

Their fluffy fresh-baked thick toast is juuuust how I have it in Japan! I always stop by here to either buy that or the raisin bread. 

Their cakes are very delicious and just how all the patisseries in Japan make 'em :) 
Their strawberry shortcakes are the best, though I looove the fruit tarts and chocolate cakes as well.
author: Saori E.

description:
Mmm, pastries. 

It's another Asian-Euro type of bakery. Cool, whatever.
