I love croissants. If they can do something different with a croissant (that I like), even better. 

They put red bean in one. RED BEAN PASTE WITH RED BEAN BITS. 

It was delicious. Soft, fluffy, ethereal croissant with dense, sweet-but-not-too-sweet red bean. YUM. 

And I didn't know this, but Anderson and Grain D'or are one and the same company? Go figure.
author: Ingrid C.

description:
SQUARE WHITE BREAD LOAVES. for your Japanese "sando" needs. For $7.

Everything else is shit.
author: Y K.

description:
Walks by Andersen Bakery.

My Stomach:  Grrrr rraarrrarrrrr

My eyes: (Googles over the cake)

My mouth: (Drooling)

My conscience: (Don't do it!)

My stomach: (Screw that!  Feed me!  Try it!  You're going to work it off later at the gym!)

Me: "Can I get a slice of the Dream Cake?"

My eyes: (Wanders and sees pound cake)

Me: "And a loaf of pound cake, please."

My eyes: (Sees cinnamon bread up top!)

Me: "Oh, and a loaf of cinnamon bread.  That will be all."

My butt and thighs: (Oh, great.  We're going to be sore for the next few days from the gym!)

That should sum up my experience at Andersen Bakery.  This Anderson Bakery located in Japan Town is EVIL.  They make the stuff look good and they taste good too.  The Dream Cake is so light and fluffy that each bite makes you feel like you're slowly floating up in mid-air....as if you're flying in a dream!  The pound cake is equally as yummy.  But the cinnamon bread was okay.  It wasn't as gooey as I thought it would be.
author: Winnie F.

description: Creamy French, Salt Stick and soup - yum! Chicken salad on raisin was amazingly yummy, their bread is so soft, sweet service.
author: Free L.

description:
The pastries tasted old and weak. Like they've been left out or something.

And by golly, who adds pepper into a blueberry cheese bun thing!? Why would u add pepper into a pastry?!?! It doesnt make sense..

I am not coming here no more, I dont want to risk soiling my taste buds on pastry buns that basically suck~ -_-
author: phillip w.

description:
I would have given a one star, but the bakery goods aren't bad.  Ordered a turkey sandwich, and was truly amazed how any one would have the nerve selling a pre-made (ala roach coach) with one slice of meat, and then charge $7.  I've had a better sandwiches out of a vending machine.

Do yourself a favor, don't order any sandwiches.  I went to Honey Baked Ham on the following day, and I could have made 10 Andersen's sandwiches with the amount of meat Honey Baked Ham provided.
author: Ed D.

description:
Bakery chains aren't my thing...like I can't stand Sheng Kee. I like the real thing where they make everything on site like Ambrosia and Mazzettis. 

That said, Andersen churns out quality baked morsels that are worth ignoring what I just said. Everything looked positively yummy. We only had room for pastries and bread, and both were quite lovely. Sweet and savory...they have it all. There's one at Serramonte too.
author: Virg Y.

description: loved their creamy french bread! the cashiers were very patient in answering the questions i had about the food there. i enjoyed my experience at andersen!
author: Louis O.

description:
The BEST Apple Raisin Bread I've had.  And it was only $2.25 for a half loaf.  Small raisins throughout, big chunks of apples at the bottom.  The crust was soft and chewy.  And the inside felt like I was eating a pillowy marshmallow!  

Too bad I rarely come to Japantown but dang that was good bread.
author: J T.

description:
The uninitiated might find having a good European bakery in the middle of Japantown as incongruous. In actuality, good European bakeries are just about in every Japanese town with Andersen's being one of the most popular chains. When I took my French cousin to one in my Tokyo neighborhood to buy a baguette, he paid the place the highest compliment possible coming from a Frenchman, "they wouldn't go out of business if they were in Paris."

I regularly pick up a loaf of their unique sourdough whole wheat bread whenever I happen to pass by. Their European style danishes are decent. Last but not least, they have the perfect marriage of East meets West, anpan!
author: David P.

description: Sometimes I feel like giving in and getting a treat after a huge bowl of noodles and an hour of wandering around the Japanese bookstore, but rarely.  I've been known to get the cheese danish, but the truth is, it freaks me out that all their pastries are laying out like people on a beach, exposed. So exposed. To oxygen and germs and flies. I saw a couple flies in there once, dancing and frolicking across raisins and glazed over pastries and whatever else was in there. Do you know what flies do??? Exactly.
author: Natasha P.

description:
I was impressed, happy and wanted more...;) Their crme brule was perfect and the fresh blueberry tart --- yum! It's not easy to get my yum vote, but Andersen Bakery you are on my mind!!!

Highly recommended if you are a mozzarella fan their sandwich with FRESH MOZZARELLA & EGGPLANT...

When is next lunch break?!!
author: Katja S.

description: I'm so glad they added a location here as I really love their Pisano and Pesto bread. It's conveniently located near my mom's place and used to be a place I would go for lunch before heading to work. Try the turkey sandwich on sour dough..it's got CUCUMBERS in it. It's not made on site, but gets delivered daily as do their other sandwiches. Come early as the sandwiches usually go by noon. Also try the Cappuccino cake, which my mom had to request that they bring back. It's very similar in taste to a Tiramisu. *Drools* And the breads they have are always very fresh, again get their EARLY! Another note is that the lady who owns it tends to remember you after a few times and usually knows what you want right away. They've also been known to stay open a little past normal hours if their are people still interested.
author: Petra S.

description:
i must admit i was a teensy disappointed at the variety and quality of what was offered at this Andersen's Bakery in J-Town.  Only bc I've been to the ones in Japan do I know what they're capable of....and those were delightfully delicious. Anyway, even though the variety is not as impressive, the strawberry and raspberry criossants and rolls I've had are both REALLY good.  Their garlic french bread is also very delicious.  I could munch on one all day.

Their locations in Union City and Great Mall in Milpitas are bigger, and offer a slightly larger inventory of things.  But their cakes look heavenly, and their express sandwiches (I had the chicken salad one) for grab-n-go aren't too shabby either.  

Nice place to satiate my carb cravings, but oh how I wish more of what they offer in Japan could also be offered here :'(
author: Peggy W.

description:
Disregard anything if it is not the square premium white loaf bread that Andersen's perfectly bakes for my belly.

Actually, I haven't tried much else, and what else I have had have been quite good, but everything pales in comparison to this ambrosial lump of dough perfectly manipulated into a cube, then sliced to your desired degree of thickness.

As Korea tries to do everything that the Japanese do, I remember eating sandwiches my mom used to make for me as a child on this kind of bread. It's divine, harnessing a moist, feather-light, spongy, silky, stretchy texture that is inimitable and incomparable. Plus, the crust doesn't have any of that unpleasant cardboardy bitterness that some breads have. Wonder, eat your heart out.

You'll never go back to plain white bread after you've had this stuff.
author: Nuri K.

description:
one of my favorite bakery shop in city.
love their creamy french and almond croissant.
also cappuccino b-day cake.. love to stop by when I am in japan town.
author: Tina L.

description: I usually visit this bakery inside Kintetsu Mall in J Town when I am in the area.  I like the flakiness of the dough on the fruit pastries or danishes and particularly on the blueberry pastry and strawberry pastry there is a nice amount of fruit topping.  Not so on the dark cherry pastry or the apricot danish where you only get a little fruit.  I like the international cheese bread here also.  On occasion I've purchased the strawberry shortcake slices also.  It's not as good as the ones served up at Junior's in New York City, but it's good.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
An Pan. Say it with me... An... Pan. So simple and so delicious. Bread, mushed up sweet beans. A couple of sesame seeds. Ahhh, harmonious. And the an pan here it top notch.

The other baked goods look delicious and likely are, if the an pan is any indicator. Maybe some other time.

EDIT 9/30/2007:
So I had breakfast at the one in Ueno Station today (or Yesterday) and I have to say the one here does compare favorably. I mean, there was no an pan at the one in Tokyo. Is an pan too low brow?
author: neil c.

description:
http://www.andersenbakery.com/index.php
In the Kintetsu Mall, across from Mikado Kid's corner, http://www.yelp.com/biz/wsUIuY6l4yTICAwrQGlSNA you just park underground of the Japantown  parking lot, use the elevator to go upstairs, turn left when you exit and you will see the Bakery.  It is tiny, a little storefront and there is seating with benches and tables next to it.
French pastries, danishes and breads.  The fave Japanese desserts of strawberry shortcake, compote cake and chocolate dream cake.  Cakes are also sold by the slices so you try all different kinds.  They also have that Japanese bread, it is white and square shaped wrapped in cellophane, would always crack me up when I would see it.  The breadpans in Japan must look different their ours!
So on my way down to the car, I pick up a box of desserts for home.
author: Deb N.

description:
The aroma from the bakery will capture your senses when approaching the area....bought the raisin bread roll for $1.80 and it was delicious. I noticed that they sell hot cross buns too, reminds me of childhood story books which feature these buns! Awww.....

Just realized that Yelpers have been raving about the sandwiches too. Hmm, will be back the next time to try them out!
author: Yan M.

description:
I love all of their items: pesto bread, croissants, filled croissants, shokupan, raisin bread and cheese bread.

When I was young (and it was called Grain D'or) My mom used to always buy raisin bread when it was fresh out of the oven so visiting it now brings back some great memories. I wish they still had the chocolate swirl bread though!!!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I like the "French cream". 
But last time when I got one, 
there is only little bit cream. 
They raised the price and less cream!! 

WHY!!!!!? 

And now they don't have the cheesecake. 
So I don't go back again!!
author: Ken N.

description: Every time I'm in J-Town, I stop by this place for my cream cheese walnut bread.  My absolute favorite here.  It's hard to resist everything else because they all look so good, but I always end up getting that.
author: Lucky M.

description:
Ahh Andersen Bakery,  splendid quality oishii european bakery! I am pleased to find this bakery here, since I missed the one back in Japan (& it is a huge hit there!). The goods are delicious, and not too sweet (which I like, because I'm not a fan of the extremely sweet stuff!). They have desserts, breads, muffins, pastries, etc. I recommend the flan, cream puffs, & raisin bread! All mmm mmm good! 

All the items are well crafted and displayed for your overconsumption of baked goods! Great for a midday snack, dessert, or even breakfast (hey there's no law against startin your day off with a cream puff)! 

The people are usually friendly, and prompt in helping you. The prices are reasonable and the location has a tiny place with a few tables. It is usually clean and a good place to scarf down your food!  

Thanks Andersen...of course I'm coming back!
author: Catherine O.

description: Quality and selection of baked goods was great here my only gripe is that they're not open early enough for an early riser like me.  Super friendly service as well.
author: shawn g.

description:
Andersen Bakery is the perfect stop and go!  

Andersen Bakery looks very simple and sleek.  It's adjacent to the Galleria Plaza Hotel. 

I ordered a small coffee and the seasonal pumpkin cookies.  Coffee is fresh.  Prices are reasonable.  Service is friendly.
author: Camille K.

description: I think I've taken this bakery for granted. I almost love everything from here, especially the cream cheese walnut bread. Once in a while I'll buy the thick cut toast from them because I love how tender the bread is and how distinct the butter taste is. They keep really well in the freezer and when it's time to have them, just put it out to thaw naturally for a few hours, and it's good as new. Their dream cake and creme brule are magnificent too. Try to come in as early in the day as possible, as these things get sold out fast!
author: Rika P.

description:
If all you want is your standard bakery, no better than Safeway or any other supermarket bakery, then go here especially if you like paying 1 1/2 times as much as you would there, because that is what you are going to walk out with. Bread that is stale by lunch time. Pastries aren't flaky at all - instead they have some type of sour cream cheese with jam on them and are dense. If you are a Dane like me, you will be extra disappointed as I was. Seems the Japanese founder went to Denmark, remembered what he liked and started baking them at Andersen in Japan. That has now expanded here. As a Dane who grew up loving the real flaky pastries with custard on them, the fresh soft french breads and rolls, the poppy seed rolls with a little bit of marcipan inside, on and on, you will leave without buying anything. I felt generous and did. I think the Japanese founder forgot a lot of details on that long trip back to Japan from Denmark. Namely how to really make good danish bakery items.

If you have time and really want the authentic stuff, go to the burbs... to Burlingame and Copenhagen Bakery. If you don't care and/or are not from Denmark, then feast yourself on the average gore at this place.
author: Alex B.

description:
I first tried Anderson's because they were offering free samples as I was walking through Jtown.  I tried the french bread with the cream inside and have been a fan of their pastries ever since.  

My favorite is the raspberry cream danish.  I crave it about once a week.  Their regular white bread is great for toast, and their sandwiches are pretty good.  I've been back regularly and haven't been disappointed with anything I've tried.
author: Ben D.

description:
Came here on the way to some sightseeing, Japantown - husband visited Japan and loves the culture so it seemed appropriate.  He likened the mall to what he would see in Japan and was excited.  Funny to know that one of the busiest bakeries is a European bakery.  Still splendid though.  Cream Cheese croissant and the walnut cheese croissant were delish.  Chocolate croissant, not so much though - a bit hard and had a lump of dark chocolate in the middle.  I didn't eat it and that stuff is my favorite.  Good coffee.

The blueberry and the strawberry tarts looked heavenly, I wish I tried those too...
author: Lily P.

description:
First time tried this bakery store.  I had sunrise bun (similar to chinese pineapple bun),   But sunrise bun its really good. 
Next time,  I'll try some pastries.  BTW taste better than their next door cupcake, its OVERRATED and pricey.
author: food lover t.

description:
Tasty cinnamon bread. Not too sweet. Perfect toasted with a little butter. I buy a loaf whenever I'm in the area.

Their christmas stolen is great, too. I brought a loaf into the office and it dissappeared in minutes.
author: Pat T.

description:
Creamy French!! Creamy French!!

(If you go buy the Creamy French loaves, I WILL track you down and steal your newly-purchased bread for my own consumption!)

5 stars for having tasty Creamy French loaves.
-1 star for ALWAYS running out!!
author: Elle Q.

description:
A decent sandwich and some fair baked goods, but not Arizmendi.  It's chain bakery food and it's fine for what it is, but I like the unique little bakeries in the neighborhoods that make unique pastries and breads.  This place won't have that.  But if you want a ham sandwich, you'll find a good one here.  

Don't try coming here during lunch hours.  It's packed and the line gets annoying.
author: Honey L.

description:
Yakitate Japan style, I love this bread!
A little bit $$, but pretty good bread. 
Raisin Apple Bread, so good.
author: Bai Z.

description: The pesto bread, pizza bread, and jalapeno cheese bread are delicious. I think the pesto one is my favorite, just by a little bit. They've very nice and slice and warm the bread for me. The sourdough loaf is pretty good too!
author: Annie K.

description:
Everything here is so delicious and the ladies who peddle the baked goods are so, so nice.  I've never had anything bad here and believe you me, I've tried a lot of pastries.  I'm relatively thin but the size of my ass always gives me away.

If they had fancier coffees than just a cup'o'joe, I might just die.  Or at least shit myself.

EDIT:  So, I nearly got hit by a car walking here a couple of weeks ago.  After the initial adrenaline rush, particularly considering that I kicked the fucker's door in, I continued on my way to get a nom nom pastry.  This place is THAT GOOD.
author: Frankie D.

description:
Very delicious cakes.  I love their Flan and strawberry tart. 
Very tasty pastries as well.  Anpan, croisant and oh, don't forget their creamy french!  

I wish they served better coffee, tho.
author: Mike M.

description:
I got: 

Coffee: 1.50 self serve
Saffron Raisin pastry: 1.95
Cranberry Walnut bread: 4.75.

my favorite: Creme Brulee

I had just come out of eating some really good fried chicken at another restaurant inside the mall, so I just wanted to get a pastry and coffee to sit and read my book for a while. The pastry was ok. I later tried the bread, and it was amazing. I'm going to toast a piece and put some cheese on it for breakfast. 

My roommate got me their creme brulee before, and it was amazing. while I was there people would just walk up and order four of them to go, and make sure to devour one before leaving. Definitely skipping lunch next time for that.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I was surprised....
Me and a friend walked by, and I didn't think a mall bakery would be this good. We got a crem brulee and it turned out to be a very good crem brulee. It was chilled, which was a nice touch, plus it tells me that's sanitary, since its being kept bellow 41 degrees; the thin coating of caramelized sugar was just right, not too thin or thick, nor did it leave a burnt residual taste. The custard was nice and consistent, with a semi sweat taste that didn't need much assistance from the caramelized sugar from the top. 
We went during the Cherry Blossom festival and had a sample of their english loaf bread; it was fresh and delicuous as well, with good consistancy and it wasn't too light.
author: R Y.

description: Unless I missed a secret menu that is not on display or on paper at the register, this location doesn't have nearly as extensive a menu as the one on their website. For lunch there are only a handful of sandwiches. I ordered a turkey and avocado. It was fine, but unspectacular. Since there are lots of other lunch options nearby, I probably won't be back.
author: Adam B.

description: I'd gladly feel fat for a day or two a month just to have their delectable pastry delights. Good thing I don't live near this place--I'd be one fat mofo mama. I especially love the almond croissants. Apparently their breads are really good but I can't get past eating the same things on every visit.
author: Barb B.

description: I have never set foot in this place but my boyfriend always brings me sandwiches from here and they are sooooo good! the bread is soft and the meat is freash carved. The turkey avocado on sourdough with mayo cant be beat.  I think Im drooling on the keyboard as we speak. I wish they would open one near my work!
author: M K.

description: Bought various pastries from this place on my weekend SF trip and was thoroughly happy with all that I got. Take your pick and you should be satisfied as well I think.
author: song c.

description: This place is inside the Kinokinuya shopping center.  I was looking forward to going to Andersen's bakery as I found out they were part of the same company that has Cafe Danmark in Shibuya in Tokyo, Japan.  Unfortunately they don't have the same offerings (like the katsu sandwich on fancy bread), but their stuff was still pretty good.  They mainly only had pasteries, and not so much other types of food.  I got the ham and cheese pastry, an pan (red bean bun), choco croissant, and a sweet bean paste pastry.
author: siutou s.

description: the best is the dream cake, strawberry shortcake, creme brulee, and the creamy french bread. The dream cake is like a dream!!!!! I come to Andersen's Bakery whenever I can and always buy the cake on a famiy member's birthday. It doesn't get 5 stars because I think it's a little expensive, but once you taste it, the flavor is so worth every penny!
author: Anne R.

description: The Cream french bread is fantastic. I will expect a little bit less red bean in those red bean bread, but it is still great, and every Japanese bakery tasting.
author: Carol X.

description: I love this addition to the little Japantown community.  They've got good pastries desserts, but I mainly go for their sandwiches.  They're cheap and yummy.  Turkey and swiss is my favorite.  The bread is usually very good...it's a walnut bread or something...although it's sometimes soggy if you buy at the end of the day.  Their coffee isn't half bad, either.  It's a well known chain, and I was happy to finally see it come to SF.  If you can't get yourself down to Clement Street and Schubert's Bakery, this is a good alternative.
author: Kristina R.

description: This is a place to get fresh baked breads that aren't overly sweet.  French breads are decent.  I like the creme brulee, by far the best creme brulee I've had that wasn't in a fancy sit down restaurant.  You can taste a hint of rum and its rich velvety custard melts in your mouth.  While I like the breads, I'm a fan of the creme brulee.
author: Peachie Y.

description: The staff here went above and beyond. They were not open yet but noticed we were waiting outside and let us in early since we were only looking to buy pastries. To top it off the raspberry cream cheese pastry was awesome! I will make it a point to go here again when I visit San Francisco.Also the pesto bread we bough to take home was also delicious.
author: Rick H.

description: I haven't tried everything here, but based on what I have eaten, I would bet no matter what you order, you're gonna like it. The palmiers are always delicious, as is the pesto cheese bread, both kinds of sandwiches, the anpan, and the cakes. I will usually come here after a meal if I don't have the cash needed for Cafe Hana. Two items will usually come out to just over $5 dollars, which is the minimum amount required to use your debit/credit card. ;)
author: M S.

description:
this bakery is surprisingly delightful.

even if you're full of mediocre sushi. nothing to wash the gross taste of eel right out of your mouth like a giant slice of strawberry shortcake & a carton of milk.

mmm, delicious.
author: Irene S.

description: Jonesing for a little dessert after an evening in J-town led us to this chain bakery in the mall. Truth be told, we went to Sophie's Crepes first, but it was a chaotic zoo, so we wandered across the foot bridge to see if Andersen's was even open (which they were). The prices are really reasonable, but I was a little put off when the counter guy came around to ask us to hurry up and finish because they were closing in ten minutes (we were practically done, anyway), but did not ask the same of any of the other dining room patrons. Also, neither of us was very impressed with our selections -- the Bread Pudding was soggy and had a dollop of some unidentifiable fruit compote in its center, whereas the Dream Cake should be renamed Dry Cake. Maybe their many other offerings are better, but I can't see myself rushing back here for second chances after this lackluster demonstration of quality and service.
author: Gregor G.

description: Perfect for a quick stop of snaking!  the bf ordered a cheese and garlic blossom thing and a cheese danish for me! :D  OMG so freaking good!! The danish was flaky and the cheese was perfect, man i want another one now.  The service was friendly and fast!
author: Hana ..

description: I love LOVE the creamy french from here!  They're so bad for you but at the same time they're just soooo goood! You have to get them early or sometimes they might run out later in the afternoon.
author: JenJen W.

description: just got back from japan town and ordered 3 loafs of the creamy french bread and i am loving it. This is my favorite from there. yummmmmm. Oh yeah and it's only $2.00 per loaf.
author: zoey x.

description: The workers here are nice and helpful. They have a variety of pastries and desserts that taste great. They have drinks and great snacks as well. They have some tables to sit and eat at, or you can eat at benches that are in the hall of the mall that are right by the bakery. Some of the pastries have cheese or meat in them.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: The spandorour and danish creams are delicious. They got so many  variety of pastries, it's like breakfast in heaven~ I think that's another store located in the heart of downtown on market and Kearny st. But the one in japantown is cleaner and nicer.
author: Michael K.

description: Bad day at the office? Have a cream puff! Not an overpowering sweetness but enough to mend any aches your daily stress may cause. Points for accepting credit cards and for the fact that the women on staff are always [sincerely] smiling.
author: Selina L.

description: Really good chicken & provolone sandwiches!    The basil makes the sandwich!  I really shouldn't say anything because they already run out of them so early everyday.
author: K M.

description: "Texas Toast" is so much more appealing when you're at an Andersen's actually in Japan, and it's the closest to sandwich bread you can find. I can't say it doesn't warm my heart to see this little stand, but it does make me nostalgic for the two-story one in the Hiroshima plaza. Stateside, my stomach growls more for Sheng Kee's pork and taro buns than Danish by way of Japan.
author: Spratt M.

description: Friendly service. Small chocolate chip cookies are good. I recommended the cheesecake. Its my favourite cheesecake in SF so far... very light and smooth.
author: hime s.

description: Last Sunday was the first time I've been to this bakery. Its too bad we do not have this in San Diego.  My girlfriend suggested this place and raved about how I have to try the Jalapeno Cheese Bread.  She was totally right!  That is the best Jalapeno bread I've ever tasted.  We also tried the Cream Cheese Schnitten (austrian sweet bread with creamcheese filling) that was amazing.  Before my trip back to San Diego, I made the mistake of only purchasing 2 jalapeno breads and one of every flavor of cheese bread.  The pesto ranks 2nd and the international cheese 3rd.  The next time I'm up there, I'll make it a point to stock up on the Jalapeno Bread.  This place is a must see!
author: Kay C.

description: They have different items than ACME or other breadshops. Andersen does loafs, Japanese style breads, and delicious pastries. Their large cheese pastry is humongous and really cheese-y.
author: Ryan Y.

description: Good pasteries but it's no La  Farine or Tartine.
author: Jen Y.

description: This must be what Beard Papa is trying to do with their cream puffs.  If you think a great cream puff should be large, spongy, and generous on the custard, come here.  Skip the chocolate muffins which are dry, dry, tasteless, and dry.
author: CAKE E.

description: I went here by myself during a stroll through Japantown and I decided to give it a shot. I had a strawberry croissant which is basically a croissant with a few strawberries nestled in the middle of it, it rocked my socks. This place is fine to go by yourself or with one other person, but don't go with a group since the tables only have two chairs a piece. It isn't expensive at all, so give it a shot. I payed $3 for my strawberry croissant and a carton of milk. Definitely well worth it.
author: Clara M.

description: I like it!  Their strawberry tart was divine.  Sometimes I wish they would serve more savory things though, to prevent me from making ham and pineapple crepe mistakes around the corner.
author: Molasses C.

description: Ever since this bakery opened up in Jtown, I've been in love. Their pastries are addicting, especially their cream puffs and chocolate eclairs! Carb heaven!!!!!!
author: kristin e.

description:
mmm carbs... i love carbs and bakeries...
this andersen bakery has some good pastries and breads and desserts
author: charlotte s.

description:
oishii!!!
the bread is fresh and damn soft. i believe this place is way better then sogo and sheng kee. we bought a fresh loaf of bread. they put the whole thin in a machine to cut their perfectly aligned thick slices.

the coffee also smelled really good...

i haven't tried anything else here. i also did not know that this was an european bakery. i thought this thing was owned by japanese, but then again the name doesn't make sense. 
be sure to give this place a try if your in japan town.
author: Eric Y.

description: I reserve all my stars for the walnut cream cheese bread. It makes the world go round. Especially when paired with a double iced espresso from  Cafe Hana around the corner. Mmmmmmmmmm
author: Antoi C.

description: I love this place..my favorite is the fruit flan..but all the pasteries are delicious!!!! It's worth the calorie and carb intake.
author: Chatree T.

description: Yummy pastries. Value premade sandwiches (4$). I love the white bread. It's so much better buying fresh than from Safeway. Get the thin sliced bread for thick sliced bread is toooooo thick for anything but french toast or fatty croutons.
author: Coco K.

description: you're good i like you, you have good bread. you're awesome. i like the ones with clam chowder though and also some chesse thing i dont recall from memory only recall from taste. i'll check. but you have coffee everything i need to survive this world of monster eatery and shopaholics.
author: Carolyn Y.

description: This review applies only to their creamy French - a small baguette with a cream filling - because that's the only thing I ever bought from there. It's delicious. I can eat those things all day. They also have a wide selection of other pastries as well that looks very tempting. I hope this review does not encourage more people to get the creamy French, because they always run out of those things on me.
author: Shin H.

description: Very nice pastries! I love their breads! Cakes are good, but I think their breads are superb. Their pastries are not overloaded with sugar like other bakeries do, but just about right! I love this place for fresh rolls and loaf of bread!
author: Julie K.

description: mmm... Fresh cream puffs and strong coffee.
author: J F.

description: this place is alright. i had the cupcake with chocolate frosting. but the location is nice and it is the only american place in japan center.
author: neil r.

description: i came here once altho i'd pass by here many times. my girl and i had a little dessert in the noon time, we met up around here and we had some cheesecake, cakes, and breads. i really don't like their cheesecake for some reason, it tasted really weird. the cakes and bread was a bit better. i really like their designs and service was decent. the smell of this place, you can smell it from far away! i like the smell of bakery, because it's so bakery. lol!
author: Valerie N.

description: but what i want to know is do they have the yummy green or red bean buns like they have in japan?
author: john f.
